div.p:
XXVII 262
not referred to in this book
I feel more horror now
1 in thinking on dangers I have
run than I did at the time
of their occurrence

5
Chester When we came to that
part of the river opposite to
the village of Manenko the
first female chief we
had met two of the people
called Balunda or Bal≈ènda
came to us in their little
canoe - From them we
learned that Kolimbota one
of our party who had been
in the habit of visiting
these parts was believed
by the Balonda to have
acted as a guides to the
party maur marauders
under Lerimo whose
captives we were now
returning - They suspected
this very naturally from
the facility with which
their villages werehad ^ been found
by and as they had removed
them since to some
distance from the river
they ^ now felt unwilling to
lead us to their places of
concealment - We felt
we were in bad repute but
having a ^ captive a boy and girl to
263
to shewshow in evidence of Sekeletu
and ourselves not being
partakers in the guilt of
2 inferior men I could
freely express my desires
that all should live in peace
They evidently felt that I
ought to have taught the
Makololo first before coming
to them for they remarked
that what I advanced was
very good but guilt lay
at the door of the Makololo
for disturbing the previously
existing peace - They then
went away to report us
to Manenko -

When the strangers visited
us again in the evening they
were accompanied by
a number of the people of
an Ambunda chief named
Sekelenke - The Ambunda
live far to the North West
Their language the Bunda is
the common dialect in
Angola - Sekelenke had
fled and was now living
with his village as a
vassal of Masiko - As notices
of such men will perhaps
convey the best idea of
the ^ state - of the inhabitants to the
reader I shall hereafter
264
to the conduct of the man Sekelenke
whom I at present only introduce
Sekelenke had gone with
his villagers to hunt elephants
on the right bank of the
3 Leeba and now was on
his way back to Masiko -
He sent me a dish of
boiled zebra's flesh and
a request that I should
lend him a canoe to
ferry his wives and family
accross the river to the
bank on which we were -
encamped - Many of Sekelenke's
people came to seesalute the first white
man they ever had an opportunity
of seeing but Sekelenke him-
self did not come near,
We heard he was offended
with some of his people for
letting me know he was
among the company - He
said I would be offended
with him for not coming
and making some present,
tThis was the only instance
in which I was shunned
in this quarter - As it

As it would have been
impolitic to pass Manenko
or any chief without at
least shewingshowing so much respect
as to call & explain the objects
265
of our passing through the country
we w waited onetwo entire days
for the return of the messengers
to Manenko - And as I could not
hurry matters awI went into
4 the country ajacentadjacent to search
for meat for the camp -
The country is coveredfurnished largely
with forest having occasionally
open lawns covered with
grass not in tufts as in
the South but so closely
planted one cannot see the
soil - We came upon a
man and his two wives and
children burning coarse
rushes and the stalks of
Tsitla growing in a brackish
marsh - in order to extract
a kind of salt from the
ashes - They make a funnel
of branches of trees and
line it with grass rope woven
twisted round untilluntil it is as if it it were a be
beehive roof inverted - The
ashes are put into water in
a calabash and then it is
allowed to percolate through
the small hole in the bottom
and through the grass - When
this water is evaporated in
the sun it yields sufficient
salt to form a relish with
food - The women and
266
fled with precipitation, but we
sat down at a distance and
and allowed the man time
to gain courage enough to
5 speak - He however trembled
excessively at the apparition
of before him - but when
we explained our object was
to hunt game and not men
he became calm and called
back his wives - We soon
afterwards came to another
manparty ^ ^ on the same errand with
ourselves - The man had
a bow about six feet long
and iron head arrows
about thirty inches in length
He had also wooden arrows
neatly barbed to shoot in
cases where he might not
be quite certain of recovering
them again his arrows - We soon
afterwards get a zebra and
gave our hunting friend
such a liberal share he we
soon became friends - All
whom we saw that day
then come with us to the
encampment to beg a little
meat - and as they have
so little salt I have no
doubt they felt grateful
for what we gave -

SekilennkeSekelenke and his people
267
defiled past our camp twenty
four in number carrying large
bundles of dried elephantselephants'
meat - Most of them came to
6 say Good bye and Sekelenke
himself sent to say he had
gone to visit a wife living
in the village of Manenko -
As he was probably in the
party before us I replied
that it was all right and when
my people came up from
up from Masiko I would
go to my wife too - It was a
mere African manoeuvre
to gain information and
not commit himself to either
one line of action or another
with respect to our visit
Another zebra came to our
camp and as we had friends
near it was shot - It was the
Equus Montanus ^ finely markmarked down to as indeed
the feet
^ as all the zebras are in these
parts though the country
is perfectly flat

Dennett To our first message
of an offer of to a visit ^ of explanation to Manenko
we got an answer with a
basket of Manioc roots that
she we must remain where
we were till she should visit
us me - Then Having waited
two days for her ^ already other messengers
268
came ^ with orders for me to come to
her - after four
days ^ of rains and negotiations
with this
lady This I declined ^ going at all and proceeded
up the river to the village of
Manenko's aunt Nyamoana
small river Makondo which
7 enters the Leeba from the
East - and is between twenty & thirty yards ^ broad

Jany-January 1st 1854 We had heavy rains almost
every day - Indeed the rainy
season had fairly set in
Baskets of the purple fruit
called Mawa were ^ frequently brought
to us by the villagers not for sale
but from
a belief
that their
chiefs would
be pleased
to hear that
they had
treated us
well - We
gave them
pieces of
meat in
return - When
crossing ^ at the ^ confluence of the & Leeba Makondo one
of my men picked up a
bit of a steel watch chain
an of English manufacture
and we were informed
that this is the spot where
the Mambari cross in coming
to Masiko - Their visits explain
why Sekelenke keepspt his
tusks so carefully - These Mambari
are very enterprising tradersmerchants
When they mean to trade with
a town they deliberately begin
the affair by building huts
as if they knew that little
business could be transacted
without a liberal allowance
of time for palaver - They
bring in Manchester goods
to the heart of Africa - these
cotton prints look so wonderful
269
the Makololo could not believe
them to be the work of mortal
hands - The Makololo oOn
questioning them ^ Mambari, they were answered
8 that English manufactures
came out of the Sea and
beads were gathered on its
shore - To Africans our
cotton mills seem are fairly
fabrications dreams - "How can
the irons spin weave and
dy print so beautifully" - The Sea
Our country is like what Taprobane was
to our ancestors - a strange realm
of light whence th came the diamond
muslin and peacocks & Explanation
of whour manufactures produces
the expression "Say, ye are gods!"

When about to leave the
Makondo - one of my men had
dreamed that Mosantu was
shut up in a stockade and
unable to a prisoner - this
dream depressed the spirits
of the whole party and when
I came out of my little
tent in the morning they
were all sitting the picture
of abject of sorrow - I askeddemanded if we
were to be guided by a
by dreams or by the authority
I derived from Sekeletu
and ordered them to load the
boats at once - They seemed
270
seemed ashamed to confess
their fears but the Makololo
picked up
courage and upbraided them ^ others with their for having
such superstitious views and said
this was always their
way if If they a certain
9 bird called to them even
they would turn back from
an enterprise, saying it was
unlucky - They entered the
canoes at last, and
were the better of a little
scolding for being inclined
to put dreams before my
authority - It rained all
morning, but about eleven
we reached the village of
Sheakondo Sheakondo on a small stream
Lekone named Lekone ^ Longkonye We sent a
Longkonye salu message to the headman,
at once and he soon appeared
with two wives bearing
handsome presents of
Manioc - Sheakondo could
speak the language of the
Barotse well, and seemed
awestruck when told some
of the "words of God" - He
manifested no fear, always
spoke frankly, and when
he made an asseveration
did so by simply pointing
up to the sky above him
271
The Balonda cultivate the Manioc,
or Cassava, extensively - , also Caffre
Sorghum, - Earthnuts, beans
maize, - sweet potatoes and
yams - here called "Lekoto", But
we see only the outlying villages
10 yet -

The people who came with
Sheakondo to our bivouacment
had their teeth filed to a point,
by way of beautifying them,
though though those which
were left untouched were
always the whitest - They
are generally tattoed in various
parts, - but chiefly on the abdomen
The skin is raised in pieces
small elevated
cicatrices,
each nearly inhalf ^ an inch long and a
quarter of an inch in diameter,
so that a number of them
may constitute a star or
other device - The dark colour
of the skin prevents any
colouring matter being
deposited in these figures,
but they love much - to
have the whole surface
anointed with a comfortable
varnish of oil - In their
unassisted state they depend
on supplies of oil from
the Palma Christi or castor oil,
or from various other
oil oliferous seeds, but they
272
they are all excessively fond
of clarified butter or ox fat
Sheakondo's old wife presented
some manioc roots and then
politely requested to be anointed
11 with butter - As I had been
liberally supplied by the Makololo
I gave her as much as
would suffice, and as they
have so little clothing I can
readily believe she felt her
comfort greatly enhanced
thereby

Bristow The favourite wife who
was also present was equally
anxious for butter - She had
a profusion of iron rings
on her ankles to which were
attached little pieces of sheet
iron to enable her to make
a tinkling as she went in
her mincing African style -
The same thing is thought pretty ^ by our own
dragoons
in walking
jauntily

We had so much rain
and clouds - I could not get a
single observation for either
longitude or latitude for
about a fortnight - Yet
the Leeba does not shewshow
any great rise nor is
the water in the least discoloured
It is slightly black from
the number of mossy rills
which fall into it - Soon
12 273
It has remarkably few birds
and fish while the Leeambye
swarms with both It is noticeable
that alligators
here possess
more of the
fear of man
than
in the
Leeambye
The Balonda
have taught
them by their
poisoned
arrows to
keep out of
sight - We
did not see
one basking
in the sun -
The BalondBalonda
set so many
little traps
for birds
but few
appear - I observed
however many (to me) new
small ^ birds ^ of song on its banks - More
rain has been falling in
the East than here for
the Leeambye was rising
fast and was working
against the sandy banks
so vigorously a slight
yellow tinge was perceptible
though it soon lost
them when the sand was
allowed a few hours to
settle at the bottom of the
glass -

One of our men was bitten
by a non-venomous serpent - and
of course felt no harm The Barotse
concluded this was owing to many
of them being present and seeing it
as if the sight of human eyes could
dissolve the poison & act as a charm

On the 6th January we reached
the village of another female
chief named Nyamoana
who is said to be the mother
of Manenko and sister of
Shinte or Kabompo the
greatest BalondBalonda chief in
this part of the country
They had but recently come
to the present locality and
274
erected atonly twenty huts - The
husband Sa-mo-ana was
13 clothed in a kilt of green and
red baize and was armed
with spear - broad sword
of antique form about eighteen
inches long and three broad
The chief and her husband
were sitting inon a skins placed
in the middle of a circle
twenty paces in diameter
a little raised above the
ordinary level of the ground
and having a trench all
round it - Outside the trench
sat about a hundred persons
of all ages and sexes - The
men were all well armed
with bows arrows spears
and broad swords - Beside
the husband sat a rather
aged woman having a
bad outward squint in
the left eye - We put down
our arms about forty
yards off and I walked
up to the centre o of to the circular bank
and saluted him in the usuall
way of by clapping the hands
together ^ in their fashion he pointed to his
wife as much as to say
the honour belongs to her
I saluted her in the same
way and a mat having
been brought I squatted down
275
in their front -

The talker was then called
and I was asked who was
my spokesman - Having pointed
14 to Kolimbota who knew
their dialect best the palaver
began in due form - I explained
the real objects I had in
view without any attempt
to mystify or appear in
any other character than
my own, for I am have
always been satisfied that
even though there were
no other considerations
the truthful way of dealing
with the uncivilized is
unquestionably the best -
Kolimbota repeated what I
had said to him to NyamoanasNyamoana's
talker - He delivered it all
verbatim to her husband and
he repeated it again to her
It was thus all rehearsed
four times over in a tone
loud enough to be heard by
the whole party of auditors
The an response came back
by the same round about
route beginning at the
lady to her husband - &c -

After explanations and
re-explanations I percievedperceived
that our new friends were
276
were mixing up my message of
peace and friendship with
Makololo affairs and stated
15 that it was not delivered on the
authority of any one less than
that of their creator and
that if the Makololo did again
break his laws and attack
them the guilt would rest
with the Makololo themselves
and not with me - The
palaver then drewcame to a close -

By way of gaining their
confidence I shewedshowed them
my hair which is considered
a curiosity in all this
region They say - "Is that hair!!
ItsIt's the mane of a lion &
not hair at all -" Some thought
I had made a wig of lion's
mane as they sometimes
do with the fibres of the Ife
and dye it black ^ & twist it so as to
resemble a mass of their own
wool - I could not return
the joke by telling them that
theirs was not hair but
wool the wool of sheep for
they have none in the
country and even though
they had as Herodotus
remarked the sheep are clothed
with hair and men's heads
with wool - So I had to
277
to be content with asserting that
mine was the real original
hair such as theirs would
16 have been had it not been scorched
and frizzled by the sun - In proof
of ourwhat the sun could
191 do ^ I compared my own
bronzed face ^ & hands then about
the same as in colourcomplexion as
the lighter coloured Makololo
with the white skin of
my chest - They readily
believed that we might be
of common origin after all
as they go readily naked
and fully exposed to that
influence Here as everywhere
when heat and moisture
are com-binedcombined the people
are very dark but not
quite black - There is
always a shade of brown
in the vemost deeply coloured
I shewedshowed my watch and
pocket compass which are
considered great curiosities
but though the lady was
called on by her husband
to look she would not be
persuaded to approach near
enough

Robinson These people seem
more superstitious than
any we had yet encountered
278
Though still but building their
village they had found time
17 to erect two little sheds inat the
chiefs circle dwelling in it
in which were placed
two pots containing ^ having charms
in them , When asked what medicine
they contained they replied "medicine
for the BaruimoBarimo (gods or departed
spirits) but when I rose
and looked into them they
said they buwere medicine
for the game - Here we
saw the first evidence of
the existence of idolatry in
the remains of an old idol
at a deserted village - It was
simply a human head carved
on a block of wood - Certain
charms mixed with red ochre
and white pipe clay are dotted
over such when they are
in use - And a crooked stick
is used in the same way
for an idol when they have
no carver -

As the Leeba seemed
still to come from the direction
in which we wished to go
I was desirous of proceeding
farther in the same direction
with the canoes - but Nyamoana
was anxious that we should
allow her people to conduct
279
us to her brother Shint√© and when
explained the advantage of
water carriage she represented
18 that her brother did not live
near the river and moreover
there was a cataract in
front fover which it would
be difficult to convey the
canoes - She was afraid too
Balobale that the Balobale whose
country lies to the wWest of
the river not knowing
the objects for which we
had come would kill us
To my reply that I had been
so often threatened with death
if I killvisited a new tribe
that I was now more afraid
of killing anyone than being
killed - she rejoined that
the Balobale would not
kill me but the Makololo
would all be sacrificed as
their enemies - This produced
considerable effect on my
companions and inclination
to follow the plan of Nyamoana
and go to the Town of her
brother rather than ascend the
Leeba - The arrival of
Manenko herself on the
scene threw so much weight
into the scale on their side
that I was forced to yield
the point

280
Manenko was is a tall strapping
woman about twenty her husb
19 distinguished by a profusion
of ornaments and medicines
hung round her person as
The latter are
supposed to
act as charms. She Her body was smeared
all over with a mixture
of fat and red ochre as
a protection against the weather
a necessary precaution
for like the rest of the Balonda
ladies she was otherwise
in a state of frightful nudity
This was not from want
of clothing for being a chief
she might have been
as well clad as any of her
subjects but from her
peculiar ideas of elegance
in dress - When she arrived
Sambanza with her husband SambanzaSambanzax
they listened for some time
to the statements I was making
to the people of Nyamoana
and the husband acting as spokesman
commenced an oration
stating the reasons for their
coming and during every
second two or three seconds
of the delivery he picked up
a little sand and rubbed
on the upper part of
his arms and chest - This
is a common mode of
salutation in Londa, and
281
when they wish to be excessively
polite they bring a quantity
20 of ashes or pipeclay in
a piece of skin and take
up handfuls and rub it
on the chest and upper
front ^ part of each arm - Others
drum in saluting drum their
ribs with their elbows
and others touhch the ground
with both chone cheeckk after
the other and clap their
hands - The chiefs go through
the manoeuvre of rubbing
the sand on the arms
but only make a feint
at picking up some - When
Sambanza had finished his
oration he rose up and
shewedshowed his ankles ornamented
with heavya bundle of copper leglets
Had they been very heavy
they would have made
adopt a straggling walk
Some chiefs have really
so many as to be forced
by the weight
& size to keep one foot apart from
the other and walk as if
the weight was a serious
inconvenience - The gentlemen
like Sambanza who wish
to imitate their betters do so
in their walk so you see men
with only a few ounces of
ornament on their legs walking
282
walking as if they had double
the number of pounds - When
I smiles at Sambanza's walk
21 the people remarked "that shewsshows
lordship in these parts"

Mr Wilkes Manenko was quite
decided in the policy of friendship
with the Makololo, and by
way of cementing the bond,
she and her counsellors
proposed that Kolimbota
should take a wife among
them - By this expedient
tshe hoped to secure his
friendship and accurate
information as to the
future intentions of the
Makololo - He will visit
the Balonda them more frequently, and
th having the good excuse
of going to see his wife and
the Makololo will never,
she thinks kill the villagers
among whom so near
a relative of one of their
own children dwells -
Kolimbota, I found thought
favourably of the proposition
and it afterwards led to
his desertion from us -

283
Soon after On the same
evening that On the evening
of the day in which Manenko
arrived we were delighted
Mosantu by the appearance of Mosantu
22 and an imposing embassy
from Masiko; - It consisted
of all his underchiefs, and
they brought a large Elephant's
tusk - , two calabashes of honey
and a large piece of blue
baize, as a present The last
was intended to shewshow me that
he was a truly great chief
who had such stores of white
men's goods at hand that
Dennet he could [afford to give presents
of them, - They might be intended
too, for M Mosantu - Masiko is
expressed delight by his principal
men at the return of the captives,
and at the proposal of peace
and alliance with the Makololo,
he stated ^ that he never sold any of
his own peo-plepeople to the
Mambari but only such
as his people kidnapped
from small neighbouring
tribes - When the question
was put whether his people
had been in the habit of
molesting the Makololo by
kidnapping their servants
and stealing canoes, - It was
284
admitted that two of his men
had when hunting had gone
to the Makololo gardens to see
if any of their relatives were
23 there - As the great object
in all native disputes is to
get both parties to turn over
a new leaf I explained the
desirableness of forgetting
past feuds, and accepting
the present Makololo professions
as genuine, and avoid
in future to give them
any cause for marauding
I presented Masiko with
an ox provided by Sekeletu,
as provisions for ourselves
All these people are excessively
fond of beef and butterx from
having been accustomed
to it in their youth, ^ before the
Makololo
deprived
them of
cattle-; - They
have abundance of game,
but I am quite of their
opinion that after all
there is nought in the world
equal to Roast beef, - and
in their love for it the English
show both good taste and sound
sense - - As it was nominally
for Masiko, his men were
very anxious to get my sanction
for slaughtering it on the
spot - I replied that when it
went out of my hands I had no
more to do with it - ; They, however,
285
wished the responsibility of
slaughtering it to rest with
me - If I had said ythey
24 might kill it not many
ounces would have remained
in the morning - I would have
given permission but had nothing else to make a
present
with in
return for
Masiko's
generosity

We were now without
any provisions except a
small dole of manioc roots
each evening from Nyamoana,
which, when eaten raw,
produce poisonous effects
A small bit of loaf made
from the last morsel of
maize meal from Libonta
was all my stock; - and
our friends from Masiko
were equally destitute,
yet we all rejoiced so much
at their arrival that
we resolved to spend a day
with them - The Barotse
of our party meeting with
relatives and friends
among the Barotse of
Masiko, had many old
tales to tell, and after pleasant
hungry converse by day
we regaled th our friends
h with the magic lantern
by night, - I would have
and in order to make the thing
asof as much use to all we
removed our camp up to the village of Nyamoana
